Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 04273e9f689514cabe8dbe5340a1ec024db6098c
It would be nice to have some more words here about the problem and some of the implementation hazards.
Done

Does this commit support changing Max block size of an MCTP interface?
Which currently is 255 for SMBus.

Which is the advantage of setting send_buf_size == req_msg_len? as my understanding, mctp driver already support split the request message to difference packet to send thru the bus base on the Max supported block size.

We need to set the socket buffer size so the kernel doesn't error out when we try to send a message that exceeds the current size of the socket buffer. This problem exists well before (and is separate to) the MTU for the MCTP link. This is purely a socket problem, not an MCTP problem.
Done

Is size_t the right type? `man 7 socket` says:

> The socket options listed below can be set by using setsockopt(2) and read with getsockopt(2) with the socket level set to SOL_SOCKET for all sockets.  Unless otherwise noted, optval is a pointer to an int.

The documentation for `SO_SNDBUF` doesn't seem to note anything in particular about the sizes.

See the `Socket options` and `SO_SNDBUF` sections of https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/socket.7.html
Done

I think we have to be careful about this comparison. From the `SO_SNDBUF` entry in `man 7 socket`:

       SO_SNDBUF
              Sets or gets the maximum socket send buffer in bytes.  The
              kernel doubles this value (to allow space for bookkeeping
              overhead) when it is set using setsockopt(2), and this
              doubled value is returned by getsockopt(2).  The default
              value is set by the /proc/sys/net/core/wmem_default file
              and the maximum allowed value is set by the
              /proc/sys/net/core/wmem_max file.  The minimum (doubled)
              value for this option is 2048.

Specifically, my concern is the wording about the doubling of the value ("for bookkeeping overhead").

https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man7/socket.7.html
Done

Given that we have socket-specific APIs that we share between `af-mctp` and `mctp-demux`, how do you feel about instead defining a `struct pldm_socket_sndbuf` that contains these two properties in `src/transport/socket.h` and then using that struct here instead?
Ack
See the comment on `af-mctp` about `struct pldm_socket_sndbuf`
Ack
SOCKET_H seems like something that's likely to clash with something else. The algorithm I use is to prefix the transposed header path with the library name, so `LIBPLDM_SRC_TRANSPORT_SOCKET_H`
Ack. Should we update the internal transport header file to follow this?

> Ack. Should we update the internal transport header file to follow this?

Ideally, yes.
Given this is an internal header, is the `__cplusplus` guard necessary?
Nope! Fixed.
Done

Hi Rashmica, after looking at the result I had a few further thoughts that might improve the clarity. Let me know what you think 😊 (I feel like I'm doing the thing where I drag patches out a bit 😞 sorry)

Hopefully one of my last thoughts on this 😊

We're reaching through into the members of `struct pldm_socket_sndbuf` here, which feels like a bit of a violation of the abstraction. We can instead integrate these tests into `pldm_socket_sndbuf_set()` and do an early exit if the socket buffer is already large enough.

With that, really we could rename it to something like `pldm_socket_sndbuf_accommodate()`, and invoke it like `pldm_socket_sndbuf_accommodate(&dmux->socket_send_buf, demux->socket, (int)req_msg_len)` to be less assertive about actually setting the value
Ack

I think we should pass the socket fd in as well (effectively "borrowing" it), and stash it in `struct pldm_socket_sndbuf`. That way we don't have to pass it through the other `pldm_socket_sndbuf_*()` APIs (which risks passing an through an inconsistent fd).
Ack
Can we just integrate this into `pldm_socket_sndbuf_init()`?
Yeah I was thinking it might be better there.
Based on the previous suggestions we would need to add `int socket` here.
Done
Based on the previous suggestions, this would become `int pldm_socket_sndbuf_init(struct pldm_socket_sndbuf *ctx, int socket);`
Ack

With the above we can drop the `socket` parameter to both of these (though as a result of other suggestions, they are replaced by doing the get in `pldm_socket_sndbuf_init()` and renaming set to `pldm_socket_sndbuf_accommodate()`).
Done

Should we make sure it's less than INT_MAX here? We could make `pldm_socket_sndbuf_accomodate` take `size_t` and do that check and conversion there. But it feels like the size param should be an int as that's what `setsockopt` takes.
yes, a check for that would be great 😊
Done
Done
This should be `sizeof(line)`
Done
Done
I'd like to see a test for `max_buf_size < INT_MAX` before the cast.
Done
Need to close or shutdown the socket before `free()`, otherwise it leaks
Good spot.
Need to close or shutdown the socket before `free()`, otherwise it leaks
Ack
Need to close or shutdown the socket before `free()`, otherwise it leaks
Ack
